Award.AwardTitle: Cytoplasmic streaming and amoeboid cell motility: Mathematical models and computational methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent experiments on cell locomotion through three-dimensional fibrous matrices have raised new questions about the basic mechanisms of cell locomotion. In particular, they have shown that some cells use pressure-driven protrusions called blebs to squeeze their way through the gaps in the matrix, and it has been hypothesized that this method of locomotion can be achieved without adhesive interactions with the surrounding environment. The goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive mathematical model of a blebbing cell and use this modeling framework to explore how cells use cytoplasmic streaming for locomotion. This model will be the first to provide an integrative picture of how local mechanical and chemical factors work together to drive directed cell locomotion. These models will involve the mechanochemical chemical interactions between the cytoskeleton, cytosol, cell membrane, extracellular fluid, and the surrounding solid structures. A necessary component to this project is accounting for the changing geometry of the cells. Given the complexity of the problem, efficient numerical simulations are needed to explore the models. The investigators develop a new mixed Eulerian-Lagrangian framework to unify the mathematical description of these complex interacting materials. Using this framework, new and efficient methods for solving the coupled equations that arise in the model are developed.

Many problems in biology involve interactions between mechanics complex multiphase fluids, chemical reactions, and deforming structures. For example, the dynamics of growing bacterial biofilms and the transport of mucus in the respiratory system are two such processes. Our models and numerical methods can be adapted to explore these important complex systems. A graduate student will be trained as part of this research project. This project is ideally suited for training graduate students with the broad background necessary for research in mathematical biology and scientific computation. The student will interface directly with the experimental collaborators involved in the project to learn the essential skill of communicating ideas across disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
About 50% of the material inside the cell is cytoplasm, which is a complex mixture of water and a dynamic network of proteins. The cytoplasm is a very complex material which behaves as either a solid or fluid depending on the time scale under consideration and the chemical state of the mixture. A major question is: What is the rheology of cytoplasm? We produced several works to address this question, and a numerical method designed to model complex multiphase mixtures.

One of the outcomes from this project was the development of a new mixed Eulerian-Lagrangian method for simulating poroelastic materials, such as the cytoplasm. The method is based on the popular immersed boundary method for for simulating the interaction of elastic objects immersed in viscous fluids. We extended the method to apply to materials which are elastic and porous, i.e. they allow the fluid to flow through the structure. We used the method in other works to study pressure propagation inside cells and cell locomotion. The methodology could be used to simulate a number of deformable porous structures such as biofilms, tissues, and even bones.

We incorporated the new poroelastic model into our previously developed model of a blebbing cell, and used the model to explore the significance of the rheology of the cytoplasm in intracellular pressure propagation. There were several conflicting experimental results about how pressure changes are transmitted across the cell. We used our model to show that seemingly conflicting results, were not conflicting at all. We showed that there are multiple relevant time scales, and existing simple models of cell mechanics were misleading and the experimental results had been misinterpreted. Thus, our results provided new clarity on the effects of cell rheology on intracellular pressure dynamics.

We developed a novel model for describing the mechanics of cytoskeletal extracts. This model provided new insight on previously unexplained experimental observations. We developed a simplified model of an isotropic, compressible, viscoelastic material continually assembling and disassembling. We demonstrated that spherical shells emerge naturally when the strain relaxation rate (corresponding to internal network reorganization) is slower than the disassembly rate (corresponding to F-actin depolymerization). These patterns were consistent with recent experiments, including a collapse of shells to a central high-density focus of F-actin when either assembly or disassembly is reduced with drugs. Our results demonstrated how complex spatio-temporal patterns can emerge without spatially distributed force generation, polar alignment of F-actin polymers, or spatially nonuniform regulation of F-actin by upstream biochemical networks.

Cell locomotion requires the coordination of protrusive forces to extend the front, contractile forces to bring up the rear, and adhesive forces on the substrate. These forces must be coordinated in order to achieve locomotion, but how cells achieve such coordination is unknown. We produced several works which provided new insight into how amoeboid cells coordinate forces to enact locomotion.

We used our computational models in combination with experimental data to examine how large amoeboid cells coordinate cytoskeletal contraction, cytoplasmic streaming, and surface adhesion to crawl in confined spaces. The model explained precisely how the cell coordinates its adhesive interactions cortical contractions in order to move. By exploring other strategies of adhesion coordination in the model, we showed that the particular method of adhesion coordination observed in the experiments produces is optimal in the sense of both migration speeds and robustness to the environment. This work showed that cells are coordinating adhesion in a near optimal way, but did not address how adhesion is coordinated.

In a separate work, we again used modeling and experimental data to examine how amoeboid cells coordinate adhesion with the substrate as they crawl. Our model shows that mechanosenstive adhesions which includes both force strengthening and weakening (so call catch-slip bonds) can explain how some amoeboid cells achieve a stepping motion. Our models show that this complex stepping movement need not require complex biochemical signaling, but rather is an emergent phenomenon based on the mechanics of the adhesions.

This award partially supported the training of an undergraduate researcher, a graduate student, and a postdoctoral scholar. The undergraduate continued to study applied math in graduate school, the graduate student went on to a postdoctoral position with a leading group studying cell crawling, and the postdoc is now a professor of mathematics. All of these trainees received broad interdisciplinary training including working with data and interfacing directly with experimental collaborators to learn the essential skill of communicating ideas across disciplines.


Last Modified: 04/27/2017
Modified by: Robert D Guy
